item.title: Oaktree's Poli Foresees Slowing US Economy
item.description: There are signs pointing to a slowing US economy despite the current "de-escalation" amid the ongoing tariff negotiations, according to Danielle Poli, Portfolio Manager at Oaktree Capital Management. Poli made the comments in an interview with Jennifer Zabasajja at the Qatar Economic Forum in Doha. This interview occurred on May 20. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nvidia Earnings Preview: What to Watch for in AI, Chips
item.description: Nvidia Corp. is projected to deliver around $19 billion in net income on revenue of $43 billion in the first quarter, up 31% and 66%, respectively, from the same period a year ago. The company is due to deliver its first-quarter earnings report after the bell Wednesday with a focus on the supply of computer systems based on its new Blackwell chips. Mandeep Singh of Bloomberg Intelligence has a preview.

item.title: Brazilian Airline Azul Files for Chapter 11 Bankruptcy Protection in US
item.description: Azul SA filed for bankruptcy, the latest major Brazilian airline to seek protection from creditors after struggling for more than a year of to cope with higher expenses and the lingering impact from the pandemic on the aviation sector.
item.dc:creator: Giovanna Bellotti Azevedo, Rachel Gamarski

media:content.media:description: Passengers board an Azul Airlines passenger jet at Carajas Airport, in Parauapebas, Brazil. Photographer: Dado Galdieri/Bloomberg

item.title: Control Risks Parvulescu: Trump Has a Better Chance Of Nuke Deal With Iran
item.description: Control Risks Partner for EMEA Sorana Parvulescu says out of all the conflicts the United States is engaged in, President Donald Trump has a better chance of forming a deal with Iran. Iran and the US started indirect negotiations in April in order to end a years-long impasse over the Islamic Republic’s atomic work. This interview occurred on May 20. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: US Stock Futures Stall as Focus Turns to Nvidia: Markets Wrap
item.description: US stock futures wavered ahead of Nvidia Corp.’s earnings as investors waited to gauge the impact of the trade war and outlook for artificial intelligence.
item.dc:creator: Andre Janse Van Vuuren, Sujata Rao

item.title: Qatar Airways CEO & Ex Virgin Australia CEO on Aviation Industry
item.description: Qatar Airways CEO Badr Mohammed Al Meer and Former Virgin Australia CEO Jayne Hrdlicka spoke to Bloomberg's Francine Lacqua at the Qatar Economic Forum on the future of the aviation industry, and the growing competition between Airbus and Boeing, the two leading global manufacturers of commercial aircraft. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Nissan Going Cap in Hand to UK for Loan May Spur Japan to Act
item.description: Nissan Motor Co.’s efforts to obtain a loan backed by the UK government raises the question of whether Japan will be pressured to step in and also support the struggling Japanese automaker.
item.dc:creator: Tsuyoshi Inajima, Nicholas Takahashi

media:content.media:description: The Nissan factory in Sunderland, UK.

item.title: Musk ‘Disappointed’ Trump Tax Bill Raises Deficit, Zelenskiy Berlin Trip | Bloomberg The Pulse 05/28
item.description:
Elon Musk expressed dissatisfaction with President Donald Trump’s giant tax bill, saying it undercut his efforts to slash government spending. Musk, who has announced he’s stepping back from his Department of Government Efficiency — a body that quickly became an exponent of the second Trump administration’s vision — told CBS News in an interview that he was “disappointed to see the massive spending bill, frankly, which increases the budget deficit, not just decreases it, and undermines the work that the DOGE team is doing.” In global geopolitics, Ukrainian President Volodymyr Zelenskiy is set to travel to Berlin for talks with Chancellor Friedrich Merz, according to a person familiar with his plans.
Today's guests: Lorenzo Bini Smaghi, Société Générale Chairman, Peter Oppenheimer, Goldman Sachs Chief Global Equity Strategist, Dambisa Moyo, Versaca Investments Principal. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: Trump Says Fannie Mae to Retain US Guarantees, Oversight
item.description: President Donald Trump said that as he pursues a public offering for Fannie Mae and Freddie Mac, the US government would retain guarantees and an oversight role over the mortgage giants. Bill Faries reports on Bloomberg Television.

item.title: KKR Among Companies Said to Be Proposing Taiyo Holdings Buyout
item.description: Japanese chemical manufacturer Taiyo Holdings Co. has received acquisition proposals from two companies including US investment firm KKR & Co., according to people familiar with the matter.
item.dc:creator: Takako Taniguchi, Taro Fuse, Hideki Suzuki

item.title: Dollar May Face ‘Major’ Drop in 2026, Standard Chartered Says
item.description: The risk of a “major” downturn in the dollar will increase next year if President Donald Trump’s policies add to the US debt burden but fail to boost the economy, according to Standard Chartered.
item.dc:creator: Naomi Tajitsu

media:content.media:description: A cashier at a store in Louisville, Kentucky. Photographer: Luke Sharrett/Bloomberg

item.title: Asia’s Big Dollar Unwind May Just Be Getting Under Way
item.description: The logic behind $7.5 trillion of investments from Asia is at risk
item.dc:creator: Ruth Carson, Masaki Kondo, Phil Serafino

item.title: Centrica Expands to New York With Build-Out of Gas Trading Unit
item.description: Centrica Plc is opening a trading office in New York that will underpin its growth in natural gas.
item.dc:creator: Priscila Azevedo Rocha

item.title: Shein Is Said to Weigh Switching IPO to HK Instead of London
item.description: Shein Group Ltd. is considering switching its planned initial public offering to Hong Kong from London, people familiar with the matter said, representing the latest twist in the fast-fashion retailer’s turbulent pursuit of going public.
item.dc:creator: Pei Li, Dave Sebastian

item.title: Weak Auction Keeps Pressure on Japan to Reduce Long-Bond Supply
item.description: Japanese sovereign bonds fell after an auction of 40-year debt met the weakest demand since July, adding pressure on the government to reduce issuance of such securities.
item.dc:creator: Mia Glass, Ayai Tomisawa

item.title: EU Should Reconsider Bank Trading Rules, SocGen Chairman Says
item.description: The European Union should consider whether tough new rules for banks’ trading operations are still warranted given the region wants to expand its capital markets, according to the chairman of one of the bloc’s largest securities firms.
item.dc:creator: Nicholas Comfort, Francine Lacqua

media:content.media:description: Lorenzo Bini Smaghi Photographer: Chris Ratcliffe/Bloomberg

item.title: Dalio Won’t Join Indonesia Wealth Fund Danantara as Adviser
item.description: Ray Dalio won’t be an adviser to Indonesia’s new sovereign wealth fund Danantara, people familiar with the matter said, just two months after officials announced the billionaire’s involvement.
item.dc:creator: Jun Luo

media:content.media:description: Ray Dalio Photographer: Victor J. Blue/Bloomberg

item.title: Wall Street Eyes Chinese Stocks Hedges Ahead of Tariff Deadline
item.description: Since slumping to a four-month low in April, Chinese equities have rallied nearly 25% as US-China trade tensions eased. According to 22V Research, that’s left the stocks vulnerable to yet another selloff in coming weeks and months.
item.dc:creator: Bernard Goyder

item.title: Hong Kong Asks Funds for Treasuries Plan If US Rating Cut
item.description: Hong Kong’s pensions regulator has pushed back against requests to change rules that would require funds to sell Treasuries in the event of another US ratings downgrade, and instead told funds to draw up “contingency plans.”
item.dc:creator: Greg Ritchie, Echo Wong

media:content.media:description: A man waits to board a Star Ferry Co. vessel, owned by Wharf Holdings Ltd., in the Tsim Sha Tsui district of Hong Kong, China, on Wednesday, May 28, 2014. The Star Ferry Co., founded in 1898, is a passenger ferry service operator which carries people back and forth across Victoria Harbour. Photographer: Brent Lewin/Bloomberg

item.title: New World’s Perpetual Bond Drops as Coupon Payment Date Nears
item.description: A perpetual bond issued by Hong Kong developer New World Development Co. fell to its lowest level in three months, as investors wait to see whether the company will defer June coupon payments.
item.dc:creator: Jackie Cai, Yuling Yang

item.title: Saudi Stocks Set to Be World’s Worst in May After Oil-Price Drop
item.description: Saudi Arabia’s sliding stocks are on course to be the worst performers globally this month as falling oil prices prompt concerns of slower spending on mega projects in the kingdom.
item.dc:creator: Tugce Ozsoy

item.title: Taiwan Trims 2025 Growth Forecast as Tariff Concern Lingers
item.description: Taiwan lowered its economic growth outlook for this year, reflecting concern about the impact of potential US tariffs on the archipelago’s export-driven economy.
item.dc:creator: Yian Lee

media:content.media:description: Taiwan's economy is underpinned by strong global demand for advanced chips critical to the AI boom.

item.title: China’s Citic, MAG Group to Work on $6 Billion Project in Dubai
item.description: Chinese state-owned conglomerate Citic Ltd. signed a memorandum of understanding to help finance the development of a planned 22 billion dirham ($6 billion) development in Dubai that’s set to add thousands of homes to the city’s booming market.
item.dc:creator: Zainab Fattah

media:content.media:description: Skyscrapers on the Dubai city skyline.

item.title: Dangote Ends Nigeria’s Run as Africa’s Biggest Fuel Importer
item.description: Nigeria’s time as Africa’s biggest fuel importer has ended as the Dangote mega-refinery boosts production. The title is now held by South Africa, where operational fuel-making capacity has shrunk, according to a consultancy.
item.dc:creator: Paul Burkhardt

media:content.media:description: The Dangote oil refinery in Lagos, Nigeria. Photographer: Benson Ibeabuchi/Bloomberg

item.title: Oil Swings Near $64 as Traders Weigh OPEC+ Plans, Russia Risk
item.description: Oil edged higher in a choppy session as the market juggled the outlook for more OPEC+ supply and the risk of additional US sanctions on Russia.
item.dc:creator: Alex Longley, Sarah Chen

media:content.media:description: A storage tank at an oil refinery operated by Bharat Petroleum Corp. Ltd., in Mumbai, India, on Friday, April 4, 2025. Indian refiners have rushed back to the market to seek crude supply after President Donald Trump’s threat of more penalties against Russia raised concerns over potential disruptions to oil flows. Photographer: Dhiraj Singh/Bloomberg

item.title: Goldman's Oppenheimer: 'Growing Opportunities' in Europe
item.description: Peter Oppenheimer, chief global equity strategist at Goldman Sachs, says the prospect of looser monetary and fiscal policy in Europe presents "growing opportunities" for equity investors when added to the cheaper valuation of European stocks when compared to their US peers. He speaks on Bloomberg Television. (Source: Bloomberg)

item.title: FTSE 100 Live: UK Gilt Yields Creep Higher, Pound at $1.35
Gold Edges Higher With US Data and Trade Talks in Focus
item.description: Gold edged higher after a two-day decline as the market remained in wait-and-see mode in spite of data showing improving economic sentiment and signs of progress in trade talks.
item.dc:creator: Sybilla Gross

media:content.media:description: A gold bar, part of the Czech National Bank's reserves arranged in Prague, Czech Republic, on Tuesday, Feb. 25, 2025. Gold’s recent record-breaking run has been broadly supported by haven demand, amid concern and increasing confusion over US President Donald Trump’s plan to enact sweeping tariffs.

item.title: Dutch Insurer Scraps Old-Style Chat Bots Amid Uneven AI Rollout
item.description: NN Group NV is replacing pre-programmed chat bots in client-facing roles with a version that can interact more naturally with humans, further evidence of the continued but uneven roll-out of artificial intelligence in financial services.
item.dc:creator: Charlotte Hughes-Morgan, Steven Arons

media:content.media:description: The move by NN Group highlights that Europe’s financial services industry is keen to seize on AI as a powerful tool Source: Getty Images/Getty Images

item.title: Galderma Backers Lead $4.27 Billion Europe Stock Sale Rush
item.description: A trio of shareholders in Galderma Group AG spearheaded a flurry of stock sales involving European companies that raised more than $4.27 billion combined.
item.dc:creator: Pablo Mayo Cerqueiro
